anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 11, 1962 of the Orissa High Court in First Appeal No. 61 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri and T. V. R. Tatachari, for the, appellant. N. Sinha and B. P. Jha, for respondents Nos. 1 and 2.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Raghubar Dayal, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Raghubar Dayal, J. This appeal, by special leave, is against the decree of the High Court of Orissa reversing the decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Berhampur and dismissing the plaintiffs suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on a promissory numbere executed by Kontaru Naiko, defendant No. 1 for Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: Orissa High Court reversed the decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Berhampur and dismissed the plaintiff's suit.

facts.text: Plaintiff's suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on a promissory note executed by Kontaru Naiko, defendant No. 1 for Rs. 6,000.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff money-lender obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 4  and r. 5, of the Orissa Money- Lenders Act, 1939  Act III of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, and the rules thereunder, on March 31, 1952. anchor.surface_text: dismissing the plaintiffs suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on a promissory numbere executed by Kontaru Naiko, defendant No. 1 for Rs. 6,000. The plaintiff money-lender obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 4  and r. 5, of the Orissa Money- Lenders Act, 1939  Act III of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, and the rules thereunder, on March 31, 1952.

facts.text: Plaintiff money-lender obtained a registration certificate on March 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff money-lender obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 4  and r. 5, of the Orissa Money- Lenders Act, 1939  Act III of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, and the rules thereunder, on March 31, 1952. He obtained another registration certificate in 1955 which said that the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted is Rs. 8,000. The plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954 and sued for the recovery of the amount due on this loan.

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained another registration certificate in 1955 stating maximum capital Rs. 8,000.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained another registration certificate in 1955 which said that the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted is Rs. 8,000. The plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954 and sued for the recovery of the amount due on this loan. It was companytended for the defendant that the suit was number maintainable as the maximum capital for which the plaintiff had required the registration certificate in 1952 was Rs. 2,000

facts.text: Plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954 and sued for the recovery of the amount due on this loan. It was companytended for the defendant that the suit was number maintainable as the maximum capital for which the plaintiff had required the registration certificate in 1952 was Rs. 2,000 and under the provisions of the Act. and the rules framed thereunder, he companyld number have advanced loan in excess of that amount

facts.text: Defendant contended that the suit was not maintainable as the maximum capital for 1952 registration was Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended for the defendant that the suit was number maintainable as the maximum capital for which the plaintiff had required the registration certificate in 1952 was Rs. 2,000 and under the provisions of the Act. and the rules framed thereunder, he companyld number have advanced loan in excess of that amount and that his doing so made the registration of the appellant as a money-lender void

facts.text: Defendant contended that advancing loan in excess of Rs. 2,000 made the registration void.

anchor.surface_text: and under the provisions of the Act. and the rules framed thereunder, he companyld number have advanced loan in excess of that amount and that his doing so made the registration of the appellant as a money-lender void and therefore the suit for recovery of Rs. 2,000 even was number maintainable. These companytentions were number accepted by the trial Court

facts.text: Trial Court did not accept defendants' contentions and decreed the suit against the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: These companytentions were number accepted by the trial Court which decreed the suit against the defendants with the direction that defendants Nos. 2 and 3 sons of defendant No. 1, were number personally liable and were liable to the extent of the assets of their father in their hands. The High Court, however, took a different view, accepted the aforesaid companytentions of the defendants and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Trial Court held defendants Nos. 2 and 3, sons of defendant No. 1, not personally liable but liable to the extent of assets of their father.

facts.text: High Court accepted defendants' contentions and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, took a different view, accepted the aforesaid companytentions of the defendants and dismissed the suit. The sole companytention for the appellant is that the High Court was in error in holding that the registration of the appellant as a registered money-lender in March 1952 became void when he advanced a loan in suit in excess of Rs. 2,000 in 1954

facts.text: The question is the same as in Sant Saranlal v. Parsuram Sahu judgment delivered today.

facts.text: Court holds that rules do not make registration void if maximum capital exceeded.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that in the absence of any specific provision in the Act in this case providing for the fixing of the maximum capital which a money-lender can invest in money-lending business, it was number open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard and that the rules framed by it about mentioning, in the application, the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was wanted and the mention in the certificate of the amount of the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted, do number lead to the companyclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate.

facts.text: Court does not decide the point on retrospective operation of higher denomination certificates.

anchor.surface_text: We do number companysider it necessary number to decide the other point raised with respect to the retrospective operation of the registration certificates of higher denomination obtained during the currency of a registration certificate.

facts.text: Registration certificate in force for 5 years from date granted.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 enacts that the registration certificate granted willbe in force for 5 years from the date on which it is granted.

facts.text: Object of the Act is to regulate money-lending transactions and grant relief to debtors in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: Various other sections deal with other matters which the legislature thought fit to provide for in order to achieve the object of the Act which, according to the preamble, is to regulate money-lending transactions and to grant relief to debtors in the State of Orissa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No explicit statutory authority in the Act delegates power to the State Government to impose maximum capital limits through rules; relies on textual analysis and analogous precedent from Sant Saranlal case.

holdings.text: The rules framed about mentioning the maximum capital in the application and certificate do not lead to the conclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate.
